name: sugarcane production | sugarcane | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8800/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of sugar cane (fresh matter). The yield is 66300 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 71.4%.;;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.];This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

This activity assumes sugar cane production on a plantation with a lifetime of 5 years and represents the average operation expenditures of the production of 1 kg of sugar cane averaged across the whole lifetime including establishment, operation and clearing of the plantation. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers, stillage as a fertiliser and pesticides are considered.


The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Some operations are done either by hand or mechanically; values in the inventory represent national averages. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest transport from field to farm (1 km). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest at the farm gate.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0114:Growing of sugar cane

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Brazil
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Cultivation of sugar cane with 20 % mechanical harvest and 80 % manuall harvest
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Transports are modelled with standard distances. This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography BR.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=BR
Average annual sugarcane yield: 68.7 t/ha (Macedo et al. 2004). In order to account for the input of 12 t of sugarcane cuttings (Granelli 2005; in practice usually provided by a professional breeding farm (Luiz 1996)) for setting up the plantation, the annual average yield is reduced by the mass of cuttings distributed to the 5 years of plantation lifetime to a corrected yield of: 66.3 t/ha --- Sources: Jose Granelli, personal communication, 2005, Industria de Alcool e Aguardente, Jose Granelli & Filhos Ltds, Sitio Sao Benedito Paraisolandia, Charqueada SP, Brazil. ---  Luiz J., personal communication, 1996, Usina Sao Martinho S/A Açucar e alcool, Pradopolis.

EcoSpold01Location=RER
Amount of active ingredient are averages calculated for Brazil from CETESB (1988). Substnaces that are not availabe in the ecoinvent database are approximated by inventories of superordinate chemical classes. The inventories were assigned according to Sutter (2010, Tab. 2.25). If no inventory for the active ingredient or the corresponding chemical class was available, the pesticide was approximated with the product "pesticide, unspecified". --- Sources: Sutter J. (2010) Life Cycle Inventories of Pesticides. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, St. Gallen, Switzerland.

exchanges.description:
Approximation of a sugarcane completeharvester for mechanical harvest (applied for 20% of sugarcane in Brazil, Macedo 1998). Calculated based on diesel consumption of machine operations in sugarcane production in Brazil (Macedo 1996) and on diesel consumption of the respective machine operation per hectare according to Nemecek et al. (2004). --- Sources: Macedo I.d.C. (1998) Greenhouse gas emissions and energy balances in bioethanol production and utilization in Brazil (1996). Biomass and Bioenergy 14, 77-81. --- Nemecek T., Heil A., Huguenin O., Meier S., Erzinger S., Blaser S., Dux D. & Zimmerman A. (2004) Life Cycle Inventories of Agricultural Production Systems. Ecoinvent report no. 15. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf (Switzerland).
EcoSpold01Location=CH

Negative values represent a net export of heavy metals. --- Sources: Jungbluth N., Chudacoff M., Dauriat A., Dinkel F., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M., Gnansounou E., Kljun N., Schleiss K., Spielmann M., Stettler C. & Sutter J.
